greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of partitions of n into parts 8k and 8k + 6 with at least one part of each type.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..20000 (first 361 terms from Antti Karttunen)
maple: b:= proc(n, i, t, s) option remember; `if`(n=0, t*s, `if`(i<1, 0,
b(n, i-1, t, s)+(h-> `if`(h in {0, 3}, add(b(n-i*j, i-1,
mathematica: nmax = 87; s1 = Range[1, nmax/8]*8; s2 = Range[0, nmax/8]*8 + 6;
x_ /; ContainsAny[x, s1 ] && ContainsAny[x, s2 ]], {n, 1, nmax}] (* _Robert Price_, Aug 13 2020 *)
nmax = 87; l = Rest@CoefficientList[Series[(-1 + 1/Product[(1 - x^(8 k)), {k, 1, nmax}])*(-1 + 1/Product[(1 - x^(8 k + 6)), {k, 0, nmax}]), {x, 0, nmax}], x]  (* _Robert Price_, Aug 13 2020 *)
program: A035677(n) = if(n%2,0,sum(i=1,n>>3, my(k = i*8); partitions_for_A035677(n-k,vecsort(setunion(parts8katleast(n-k,k),parts8kplus6(n-k)),,4)))); \\ _Antti Karttunen_, Feb 06 2019
xref: Bisections give: A035623 (even part), A000004 (odd part).
results.author: _Olivier Gérard_
